story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityIn a statement released through the politan Police, they said they have been ‚Äúoverwhelmed‚Äù by the public‚Äôs support.Her family said: ‚ÄúIt is a year since Sarah died and we remember her today, as every day, with all our love.‚ÄúOur lives have changed forever and we live with the sadness of our loss. Sarah was wonderful and we miss her all the time.‚ÄúOver the past year we have been overwhelmed with the kindness shown to us, not just by family and friends, but by the wider public.‚ÄúWe are immensely grateful to everyone for their support, it has meant such a lot to us and has comforted us through this terrible time.‚ÄúSadly, Sarah is not the only woman to have lost her le recently in violent circumstances and we would like to extend our deepest sympathy to other families who are also grieving.‚ÄùGroups of women in London and Glasgow have said they will be marching to show ‚Äúsolidarity‚Äù with Ms Everard‚Äôs family on Thursday evening.Marches are due to take place from pm on Clapham Common in south London, near where Ms Everard was abducted, and at Kelvingrove Art gallery in central Glasgow. vw,vw,px, px"Sarah‚Äôs death sparked vigils and protests Ms Everard, , was raped and killed by serving Met officer Wayne Couzens as she walked home in south London on March  last year.He was handed a whole-le term in September.A non-statutory inquiry has since been launched ‚Äì led by Dame Elish Angiolini ‚Äì who is looking at how Couzens was able to work as a police officer for three dferent forces despite concerns about his behaviour.Following this, there are plans for a second part that would look at wider issues in policing.Our thoughts are with Sarah Everards family and loved ones.One year on we remain deeply disgusted and shamed that a Met police officer was responsible for Sarah‚Äôs appalling murder. pic ocqwgpdlB‚Äî politan PoliceMarch , The Met has also commissioned its own review of the culture and standards at the force, including Couzens‚Äô former unit ‚Äì the Parliamentary and Diplomatic Protection Command.The past year has seen a number of high-profile alleged stranger murders of women, including the deaths of PCSO Julia James and teachers Sabina Nessa and Ashling Murphy.Another case saw labourer Valentin Lazar, , jailed for le for beating -year-old Maria Rawlings to death after a chance meeting on a bus.On Thursday evening, a walk will take place in south-west London, which organisers The Urban Angels said is in memory of ‚Äúvictims of gendered violence‚Äù.The group, which aims to make society safer for women and non-binary people, wrote it is a ‚Äúchance for us all to stand in solidarity and show that we both demand and support change‚Äù.The event will begin at Clapham North Underground station at pm and will finish at the Clapham Common bandstand, near where Ms Everard went missing and the location of a socially distanced vigil held in her memory last year. vw,vw,px, px"A walk will take place in south-west London later on Thursday in memory of Sarah and others who have died as a result of gendered violence A title: all children aged  to  can now get the covid  vaccine
story: The Public Health Agencyis calling on the parents of  to  year olds to get their child vaccinated against COVID-. While most children aged  to  will have mild diseasethey contract COVID-, some may experience symptoms which last longer than just a few days. Vaccination of children in this age group has been shown to help prevent the small number of hospitalisations and intensive care admissions that can occur in this age group. It has also been shown to help provide short-term protection against non-severe disease. Dr Jillian Johnston, Joint Interim Assistant Director in Health Protection at the PHA, said: ‚ÄúWe know the COVID risk for young children is less than for older people, but we also know the vaccine is very safe, has already been used extensively around the world, and there is no evidence that it causes any long term issues. When you look at the risk of COVID- against the risk of the vaccine, it‚Äôs more beneficial for children to receive the vaccine. It not only boosts the child‚Äôs immunity against the risk of severe disease, but helps protect more vulnerable or older family members in advance of any potential future wave of COVID-.‚Äù A new specially-designed children‚Äôs formulation of the Pfizer BioNTech COVID- vaccine has been approved for this age group and it‚Äôs given at a lower dose compared with that used in iniduals aged  and above . Like all children‚Äôs vaccines, this approval was given following a robust review of data showing that it is safe and effective to use in this cohort. Clinical trials have shown that this vaccine was highly effective at preventing COVID- in children, protecting them and also reducing the chance that they transmit the virus to others, including family members who may be more susceptible to severe consequences of the infection. Dr Johnston continued by saying: ‚ÄúIn Northern Ireland, childhood vaccination programmes have consistently achieved high coverage and we hope that parents will be supportive of this roll out and get their child vaccinated. Vaccination is the most important thing we can do to protect ourselves and our children against ill-health. Evenyour child has already had COVID-, it is still important to get them vaccinated, as being fully-vaccinated can offer them the best protection from the virus and severe disease.‚Äù From Wednesday  March  you can make an appointment for your child at a children‚Äôs vaccination clinic in your local Health and Social Care Trust using the online booking system at:covid-.hscni.net get-vaccinated. You may be able to attend without an appointment. Dr Johnston concluded: ‚ÄúCOVID- has not gone away. Getting vaccinated provides the best protection for both the child and their family. Children will need two doses of the vaccine, usually  weeks apart, to get longer-lasting protection. If your child has tested positive for COVID-, you should normally wait  weeks from the test for your child to have their first or second vaccine.‚Äù For further information for parents on the COVID-
